commentBody:
My five favorite original clues from last week
(in order of appearance):

1. Star sign?  (3)
2. Call for delivery?  (4)
3. African creature whose name is one letter away from what its horns might do  (6)
4. Not own  (4)
5. What might lead to a row at a party?  (4)(5)


CUE
PUSH
IMPALA
DENY
LINE DANCE
Really fun and clever! Loved the revealer.

I love the Garden's breadsticks: I could eat Olive them!

(It's a real pastability.)
Quite an easy solve. Great puzzle!

I drove my Chevy SIX TEN extended-CAB 
to the LEVEE but the LEVEE was dry.
Is Kiran Pandey new to creating crossword puzzles, or when it comes to constructing, is he an OG?
Obliterated my previous record of 3:40. Got 3:14. Almost hit the three minute mark, but my finger slipped a couple of times. Makes me think a three minute puzzle is doable
Destroyed my Monday record today. Fun, and I’ll take the win, but maybe a little _too_ easy, IMO. :-)
I’ll be polite and say that 62 down is certainly a new one to me, and since Google has prior usage examples, I’ll leave it at that.
I did the puzzle without reading Sam's comments and did not know there was a theme.  Now that I read the comments and looked back...oh gosh.

This puzzle went so fast I skipped a lot of downs and had to go back after solving to see what I missed. One such was OLDSPICE, which reminds me of my grandfather. I'm not usually a fan of cologne on anybody, regardless of gender, but I'd take Old Spice over Axe any day. I once was on a packed plane next to a YOUNG guy who had apparently doused himself in the stuff before leaving the house. What a headache I ended up with! And since the plane was full, I couldn't change seats. 

/daily rant

My contribution : translate the french message! :)
« Hello sky, Santa is listening to you. Phone your message, 10 grouped lines ».
Strange syntax!

“Not online” 

Off grid

Great Monday puzzle, Mr. Pandey. Well done! My only problem was the clue for CARTS [Grocery conveyances.] I just couldn't understand "grocery." What is that anyway? And does it have something to do with "groceries," that beautiful term, but so old-fashioned? It's a bag with different things in it, isn't it? Yeah, I think that's what it is. Ducking and running, but before I leave, here's ASIA with their cover version of Globus's "Orchard of Mines" – https://youtu.be/tsqvFHIgbzE?si=TqGv_yHxqlYXPiJQ

Is the answer to 42 Across still correct?
How about 45 Across?
Or 54 Across?
Or 58 Across?

There is more to this Monday than meets the eye.
[Late victory] = OVERTIME GOAL

In the 1920's, Louis Bromfield wrote some novels and Hollywood film scripts, one--*The Rains Came*--set in India; made a crapload of money; got interested in "experimental"--i.e. sustainable--agriculture; bought some 600 acres of farmland in North Central Ohio, near to his birthplace of Mansfield; and renamed the place Malabar Farm. Humphrey Bogart and Lauren Bacall got married there, with Bromfield as best man. It is now a state park. Adjacent to Malabar Farm is a hill, once named Poverty's Knob, but now known as Mt. Jeez--from Bromfield's exclamation over the view from it: "Oh, Jeez!"[sic] *** *** You don't have to be from a race of mythical beings, just free and lonely, to enjoy this bit of Schumann, as played by a very young Pinchas Zukerman: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6VWaq6jfR8M

I don’t know if this is the right place for this comment, but I would love the option to fill in all vowels. Just like you can reveal a letter or a word, on really hard days, I would like to reveal the vowels

Oh geez this one got me. Got almost all of them on my first pass. I was cruising. Then a huge roadblock. Terms I had no idea about. Oh, well. It was hardish for me in places. Still a very nice puzzle for a Monday! All y’all have a great evening! Thanks for the puzzle, Kiran Pandey!
Other OG phrases?  Anunoby?

"Flag nickname" = OLD GLORY
"Score on yourself" = OWN GOAL
Sam doesn't like Doonesbury?? Oh geez.
Got a PR today 4:47 on a phone. Maybe could have shaved off a little more if on a keyboard, but I’ll take it!

Hey, one of these could’ve been an entry in yesterday’s puzzle too:

“Drab green hidey hole for pointy jawed fish”

OLIVE GAR DEN

Yes, this was an OG clue you’ve never seen before and never will again!

I'm not a crossword snob (I generally don't have much success after Thursday), but today seemed a little too easy even by Monday standards.  But an easy one is fun from time to time, it makes me feel smart.

As for OG, I might suggest OLD GEEZER and ORGANIC GROWTH.

I'm going to assume that the emus are eating any comments that contain the two word title of the 1977 George Burns/John Denver movie? 

(If not, then why in the world hasn't anybody suggested the original "O-G" phrase? I mean OMG, C'mon)!

So enjoyable. I was literally singing little rhymes such as GLUM ALUM and RUMP OF THE GRUMP UMP. 

DELIGHTFUL. Let's have more of these puzzles.
As a GenX-er, I object. The internet is our youth. (or the Millennials, but not GenZ.
@Sam +1 for skipping “Doonesbury”!!! I still absolutely do not get it!
UMP, SAX? I know these are very common shorthands but shouldn't they be somehow denoted anyway?
In the musical of The Phantom of the Opera, the Phantom signs his notes "O.G.," which stands for OPERA GHOST.

This one was fun, and brought to mind that bit of crosswordese I used to see quite often, but not so much anymore.  That is the architectural element known as an OGee.  Would have made a great reavealer.

I'd like to be 
under the sea
In an Octopus's Garden
In the shade
Fun to start off with a nod to my home town.  Perfect level of difficulty, but still just right level of difficulty.  Great start to the week, well done, Kiran.
Mondays have gotten too easy!
Okay, I’ve never heard of the fae

(Per Sam's request):

There once was and old geezer who belonged to the old guard, and flew Old Glory, and whose olfactory glands enabled him to sniff out oat grass, which he wove to make an outer garment for when he was an organ grinder, as well as to make oven gloves, which he didn’t wear when playing online games.  The end.

I'm sure there are a few clever ways of clueing this O-G combination:
Off-Gassing: the process by which materials release gases, particularly volatile organic compounds (VOCs), into the air.

My dad shaved with a razor and brush. He used Old Spice shaving soap.
Ha ha… loved the theme; it made me chuckle. Easy Monday puzzle but fun.

Nice Monday puzzle and an enjoyable workout. The reveal was one of the very last things I filled in and that made for a nice 'aha' moment when I went back and reviewed the theme answers to see the commonality. Couldn't ask for anything more. A couple of vaguely related puzzle finds today. First - a Wednesday from January 19, 2011 by Kristian House. The 'reveal' clue and answer in that one: "Beaver Cleaver expletive ... or what you might need to be to answer 18-, 23-, 51- and 60-Across?" GEEWHIZ And then a couple of those theme clues and answers: "Cry for help on an F.B.I. cruise?" GMANOVERBOARD "Guess as to how the thong came to exist?"" GSTRINGTHEORY And the other two theme answers: GMAILROOM GSUITCASE Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=1/19/2011&g=37&d=A Might put another puzzle find in a reply. ...

Monday funday!

Gonna be thinking of OG pairings all day.

Original gangster
Overgrown
Old g…

Oh, give up CC.
Not awake yet.

Finally home.
Youngest is sitting next to me.
He’s squeezing in a quick trip 
to Sweden to spend some time with my mamma
before residency begins.

Older son got married on Saturday, 
and it was perfectly un-perfect.

Feels like a month since last Monday,
but all good.
Wonderful, even.

Now I want to sleep for a couple days.
Is that allowed?
Is that even a thing?

I want it to be a thing.

Happy Monday all!

It is very hard to construct a Monday puzzle, where the answers are commonly known to most everyone.  When you start interlocking words in a grid, lesser known words very often become the only possibilities, and you have to scrap what you’ve done and begin anew.  

(It’s okay and even desirable, to make things a bit more interesting, to have a few spread-out unknowns but they have to be very easily crossed.)

It is also tough to clue a Monday without the clues in general being so easy that the solver feels insulted.

So, making a good Monday puzzle is an art; it is not something simply dashed off, and credit to Kiran for crafting this lovely one.

I liked seeing ROMA near TOMATO, and when I saw the three answers SOFT, SHEL, and CAB, I couldn’t unsee “soft shell crab”.  

Cute elegant theme and admirable Monday build, Kiran.  It was a gift to start my day experiencing beauty.  Thank you!
No comments on the puzzle, but I'd really like some context around the photo of the French children speaking to Father Christmas.

I hadn't heard the word FAE before, but it was easy to get from the crosses, and easy to see its relationship to "fairies". Thinking about fairies, I thought of an episode of one of my favorite podcasts, "In Our Time" with the extraordinary Melvyn Bragg. https://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p003c1b3 I think of fairies as these beautiful creatures, mostly full of delight, but with perhaps a streak of mischief. But fairies have been long feared, creatures on the edge of "civilization" who might kill one's child as it slept at night, or steal it and replace it with an evil twin. It's amazing how are concepts change over time!

In our Neo-Mediaeval world, I'm prepared to accept any variant spelling of "fay/fairy," but it is telling that among its dozen or so forms, the OED  
does not list "Fae." Perhaps the reference libraries of fantasy realms are not so well stocked.

A Monday puzzle with a good mix of NEOSOUL and OLDSPICE.

I’ll just caution: be careful not to drop your theater binoculars if you’re wearing your silk elbow socks.

Coke is currently running one of their many advertising/sales campaigns wherein the labels on their bottles carry something that is supposedly "interesting". Paid no attention to this until this morning, when I noticed that the half-finished bottle of Diet Coke on my desk says "The OG".

Solid Monday puzzle, though I'd have preferred that the only Gs in the grid be the ones in the thematic entries. (Avoiding additional O's is asking too much.) Seems that the Gs in 20A, 56A and 58A can all be removed rather easily. To me, the O G from VETO/GLEAM is a bit of a construction "bug". Maybe others see this as an interesting feature. And, even more likely, I'm the only one who even noticed it. ;-)

What a nice, fun Monday puzzle. I had a few wrong guesses, but they were easy to fix. The theme put a smile on my face.

As for the word FAE, fantasy writers have been using that spelling for many years. (Another commenter has noted its use by Robert Frost.)

Once again, the Mini was mind-bogglingly frustrating. Having never seen "30 Rock", I actually had to look it up. In a Mini!
My time for the Mini almost equaled my time for the main puzzle. Can't the Minis go back to being... fun?

Speaking of fun, Happy Victoria Day to all the Canadians out there. Let's celebrate Canada!

It’s a depressing anecdote, but I’ll share it anyway as an example of how the most innocuous-sounding entry can sometimes stir up an unpleasant memory in a solver. (The story is also about one of the most surreal moments of my life.)
__________

In 1990, my 24-year old sister Andrea was hit by a car while crossing a street at night and was instantly killed. 

At Andrea’s memorial service a few days later, a woman who none of my family knew (probably one of Andrea’s coworkers) offered this remembrance of Andrea:

“I want to share something about Andrea that many of you probably didn’t know: Andrea had a substance abuse problem.”

Long pause, during which my siblings and I looked at each other with dumbfounded expressions. 

“She was addicted to the bread sticks at OLIVE GARDEN!”
__________

I don’t think that OLIVE GARDEN should be off-limits for the crossword. But in the same way that the Jackson Browne song “Fountain of Sorrow” takes me back to that funeral home in St. Louis, any mention of Olive Garden reminds me of my sister. Maybe that’s not entirely a bad thing.

Lifelong, native Floridian here, though that might not say much given the 20 brief years I've existed on this Earth.

Being driven to after-school activities when I was little, maybe 7 or so, we always used to be able to smell the sweetness of the orange groves as we drove past a half mile of them, just off the side of a somewhat major state road.

No longer do they exist, long replaced by apartment complex after apartment complex. I still think of the smell and the trees every time I pass that area.
Mini issue - some of us must use the colorblind version, so our answers are I RED!

There’s something deeply comforting about a Monday NYT crossword, and today’s puzzle delivered that familiar, satisfying ease with a touch of clever charm. As someone who relishes the gentle ramp-up into the week’s solving journey, I found this puzzle to be a delightful warm-up—like stretching before a long, rewarding run.
The theme was light and playful, centered around the phonetic phrase “OH GEEZ”, which tied together four long entries: OLIVE GARDEN, OLYMPIC GAMES, OPERAGLASSES, and ORANGE GROVE. Each one brought a smile, not just for the “O.G.” initials but for the variety and vivid imagery they evoked. Who doesn’t love a mental stroll through an orange grove or a nostalgic nod to unlimited breadsticks?
Clues were crisp and accessible, with just enough sparkle to keep things interesting. Highlights included:
“Queen of the Nile, informally” for CLEO — a classic clue with a breezy twist.
“Shake, as a dog’s tail” for WAG — simple, yet joyful.
And “Silverstein who wrote ‘A Boy Named Sue’” for SHEL, which felt like a warm literary hug.
The grid was clean, the fill smooth, and the solving experience—start to finish—was like sipping a perfectly brewed cup of coffee. No obscure trivia, no awkward abbreviations, just a well-constructed puzzle that reminded me why I love Mondays in Crosswordland.
If this is the tone-setter for the week, I’m excited to see what Tuesday and beyond will bring. Here’s to a week of wordplay, wit, and that unbeatable “aha!” feeling.

Great opening sentence @Lucas, my observations as well.

Amazing about Shel Silverstein. His name is a crossword regular, kind of like Alou, Asner, Alda. Huge kudos to Kiran for citing some of brother Shel’s best work. After some digging, I hadn't realized how influential he was, not only in writings and cartooning, but the hit songs he wrote. Wow. The things one learns by doing puzzles!

Quick note to my fellow rap/hip-hop antis, André 3000’s Ms. Jackson was written to Erykah Badu. You may not want to listen to her “Tyrone”, but it's a cool groove, nonetheless. That being said, take in the likes of early neo soul’s Jill Scott, Lauren Hill or Roy Hargrove (RH Factor)... as smooth as some Sade’, you'll be amazed. The genre is still out there, but more for we jazz aficionado-types. Toss in some Tom Brown’s Jamaican Funk (unrelated), and go back for some Al Hirt.

If that doesn't do it for you, clear your head with ZZ Top’s 41D 😉
O. G. phrase: Old Geezer
[Monotheists believe in this] = ONE GOD

Monday, Monday can't help that day.... tra la la.

Grandparents, lived in FLA, used to carp that CA grew more oranges, the second gripe was Maine, they lived there in the summer, had fewer vacationers than other states. Thus Florida should not be so tied to oranges and Maine vacations. My father stated they would complain if they were hung with a new rope. Oddly, they complained about him as well.

Thanks Kiran, a good one.

I had to wait for the crossings to get FAE.
I am more of a nonfictiion person--I write nonfiction..some of it would be termed "creative non-fiction."  I read more nonfiction than fiction, though I enjoy a good novel or mystery very much.. (O'Brian's sea novels come to mind, for instance.)  But I couldn't get past the first few pages of Tolkein, fell asleep on the movies, never picked up _Wrinkle in Time_....  yet I loved the SciFi novels of Pohl and Lem.  Perhaps my life has had too much reality?  And yet, there is _Charlotte's Web_ (and the final sentences which ring so true.)

Perhaps Kiran can next build a crossword around my favorite exclamation....GEEZ Louise....?
Nice Monday, but as always, over too soon.
And too many mentions of the Mini....

What a fun little clue this one was. A nice start to the week on Monday. One that gets me thinking but not so hard that it's adding stress to what is already the most stressful day of the week.

Thank you!

Given that I solved it in less than 35 minutes and it had a highlighted theme, I was pretty into it and satisfied! 63 down clue should have been, “what Muskrat did this past election” lol! Anyways, hope all my fellow NYTers are having a Marvelous Monday and Namaste!!

Sometimes I'm terribly bad at reading down answers. Today I took way too long to figure out HONESTABE. Even after I filled it in, I was reading it downwards thinking, what the heck is that? What kind of nickname is that? Hones tabe? Hone stabe? It wasn't until I typed it into Google that I saw what it was supposed to be.
Now THAT was a super fast solve: 3 minutes and 57 seconds.  I guess it does indeed pay to do these regularly.  Thank you, Kiran for a fun start to the week.

Taking Your Olympic Measure
Alberto Ríos 1952 –


Think of the records you have held:
For one second, you were the world’s youngest person.

It was a long time ago, but still.
At this moment, you are living 

In the farthest thousandth-of-a-second in the history of time.
You have beaten yesterday’s record, again.

You were perhaps the only participant,
But in the race to get from your bedroom to the bathroom, 

You won.
You win so much, all the time in all things.

Your heart simply beats and beats and beats—
It does not lose, although perhaps one day.

Nevertheless, the lists of firsts for you is endless—
Doing what you have not done before,

Tasting sake and mole, smelling bergamot, hearing
Less well than you used to—

Not all records are for the scrapbook, of course—
Sometimes you are the best at being the worst.

Some records are secret—you know which ones.
Some records you’re not even aware of.

In general, however, at the end of a long day, you are—
Unlikely as it may seem—the record holder of note.  

Copyright © 2021 Alberto Ríos. 

—Poetry was an Olympic event from 1912-1948.

The "Pentathlon of the Muses" refers to the five artistic disciplines that were part of the OLYMPIC GAMES art competitions from 1912 to 1948.

"office gossip”
"Organic Gardening“
“Ocean going“
My fastest puzzle ever. Once sweep across and one down.
Shouldn’t UMP, as an abbreviation, be clued with an abbreviation?
On guard!
¡Olé!  Gah.

To Ms. Corbin: What you wrote about Doonesbury not being funny was funny. It took me back to when I thought the same, until I noticed Mr. Butts. 
..and that was a fun puzzle!
Original Gangster

Very quick fun. 4m22s today. 

Nice puzzle, though.
Got my fastest Monday ever at 3:30. Fun to race through!

Busiest time of the year (lead up to the big US holidays) so new  habit is to solve in the early morning but wait until now to post.  

Worked bottom up from the "OG's" reveal so had fun solving the themers with no crosses (yay me!).  

Good fun was had by all.

What a lovely puzzle! No record, since I like to skip some Across fills to make sure I read all of the Downs, but only a handful that I didn't know from just the well written clues.

One of those was the very clever revealer, which just added to my enjoyment of the solve. And today I learned about FAE. Thanks, Kiran and Commenters!

(I didn't see a Strands post, but I recommend today's. Off to see if the other Games are as much fun!)

I very nearly solved by going straight through the across clues (even got the theme clues without crosses). My downfall was GLINT instead of GLEAM. Very obvious correction when I went through the downs though! Definitely would have beeny record were it not for that mistake.
My grandparents regardless of political persuasion preferred Peanuts over Doonesbury and I could also understand someone being too young to naturally appreciate it.
In regard to the mini: It is not “whiskey bourbon” 🙄 It is bourbon whiskey!! Love, Kentucky.
The perfect Monday.  Fun and relaxing, missed my best time by 3 seconds.  Thanks to the crew for this one.

@Lewis

Very much enjoyed your LAT puzzle last Friday, thanks for the heads-up!

@Lewis
33A in today’s New Yorker crossword 😉 .
@Mike you know why the French chef killed himself? He lost the huile d’olive!

Just stay calm if you decide to take a table outside -- don't get all frisky al fresco.

@Petrol
Why did the French chef use only one egg? Because one egg is un oeuf.
@replay Now I'm gonna have this song stuck in my head for the rest of the day. Could do a lot worse though
@Sonja - Already there for me … from this week’s NYT Acrostic!

@Michael Daly-Jones

This is his seventh NYT puzzle.

Lennie Briscoe: "That was a rhetorical question."
Card Player: "Suit yourself."





Everybody Loves Raimondo's

@Michael Daly-Jones

Good one. Too bad it wasn't included in the puzzle. I was trying to think of other OGs but never came up with the OG OG!

@Steven M.

A three-minute solve is possible.  I say that with confidence and certainty and experience.

@Steven M.

Is that on a keyboard or phone? Because if it’s phone, I’m impressed.
@Steve L The "for me" is implied. (And on a phone, since I know that my typing on a laptop would be significantly faster than on my phone)
@Elizabeth Connors Phone
@Elizabeth Connors I always solve on my phone through the website

@Larry Berger

I was thinking it's what the cartoon character Cathy used to say (is she still around?) but that was Ack. I don't know who says gah, but I've definitely seen it on Reddit here and there.

@RDB

I didn't know there was a theme until I got to the revealer, the very last across entry in the puzzle. Didn't need it for solving, but it did add a little extra something.

I got the theme right away. 
I didn't know if there would be a revealer.
I enjoyed it when I found it.


N.B. Quite a few of us don't read the column 
until after solving the puzzle.

@RDB

I see what you did there. ;-)

@Beth

That’s one of the benefits of wearing masks in a flight.

@sotto voce

Don't worry, you don't need groceries anymore. You have your two dolls, and they obviously came in a grocery bag, so you're just going to have to make do.

@sotto voce
GAH

@Barry Ancona

That depends on whether you still think there's 16 Across.

@Barry Ancona
69A!
Treat yourself to a 1A
Listen to some 38A
Take in some 40A
Take a 13D
Splash on some 8D
62D!!!!

@Barry Ancona I'd been planning to say the puzzle needed a trigger warning to the effect that so many answers would have us saying 69A or 62D (bonus points for having them cross).  22A 42A 54A 58A 65A 27D 35D 55D 63D. Yes indeed: sad times for the 16A
  Just noticed that Mr. carrot top has an unhealthy fondness for 2D regions. can something useful be done with this?
69A! Now I need some 6D to overcome my now diminished 56D.
@Xword Junkie

@Xword Junkie
Nice to bring back orthogonal!  Orthogonal FDM had its heyday in telecom, as did plesiochronous. Now, its just all Greek to me.
@Eric Hougland I wish I could have reached that puzzle from my iPad, but it was an incompatible format, so it said. 🙁

@Bill I should have mentioned that in the 30s and 40s, Malabar Farm became a getaway spot for Bromfield's Hollywood A list buddies, to evade the paparazzi and drive a tractor.

It would have been better known in 1949.

@Bill

I’m sure Malabar Farm was better known back then. But as a fan of classic Hollywood movies, I was a bit surprised that I hadn’t heard of it.

@Bill
Did Malabar come from the caves that feature in E.M.Forster's Passage to India? (One of my all-time favorites. All too timely.)

@Bill,

Ah! Thank you for clearing up that mystery for me. I saw that in the (in)famous Maleska puzzle and wondered what that was.
@Jones Doonesbury comics are shaggy dog stories told by a visiting uncle, but I welcome any evidence to the contrary!!

@Sam Corbin Doonesbury fans were originally connected to the comic strip and each other thru shared experiences, including news paper articles, during the Vietnam Conflict era. Haven't read it lately, i.e. since said era so don't know if the backstory is the same.

@Sam Corbin Doonesbury was very topical and political. The trick was to be current on whatever was going on in the politiverse.

I'm sure the comic would have featured people drinking covfefe and eating hamdergers at some point.

@Sam Corbin

So many times the joy of reading Doonesbury was reading a comic strip with characters who were saying things that nobody else seemed to dare to say and making fun of the perpetrators.  There were times when we were thrilled to see the sheer nerve of the strip.  It was important, and if you didn't get it, maybe the loss was yours?

@Sam Corbin

I don't read him every day, but when I do I still come away thinking he presents some of the best political commentary out there.

When I was in college and Doonesbury was fairly new, a group of us would often complain that the punch line was in the second to last panel.

Still, I think it's worth giving it a second chance.

@Jones
I wonder if Sam knows that Ross Trudeau is the son of Garry Trudeau?

@Sam Corbin

It's a generational thing.  Those of us who grew up with Doonesbury in the early '70s knew it to be hip and funny and edgy, joking about the draft and the Vietnam War and Nixon and drugs.  This was a time when other comics had the bite of "Nancy" and "Archie".  And "Peanuts" which had once been new and cool was now old and tired, certainly not hip.

By the late '80s and beyond, Doonesbury was getting tired, but those  of us who grew up with it still like to see what our "old friends" were up to.  Zonker and MIke and Mark and B.D. and Joanie were like Ross and Phoebe and Rachel and Chandler.  They had become part of our extended family.

You can go back and read the old comics, but you can't bring back the feeling of those who experienced at the time.
@The X-Phile This is a wonderful snapshot of what it meant in its heyday (and explains why it never hit for me). Thanks for making me appreciate it a little bit more.

@Sam Corbin

"In the beginning" (do you hear the bass notes of that?) Doonesbury was all about protesting Vietnam, and Nixon, and heady issues that love, peace, and drugs would make all better. If you were part of that generation, you knew who those cartoons represented, you watched the news (that's a program on television, a box in a room in your house), and protested The Man. You cared, in a huge way, about world politics, and were either for or against...everything. Doonesbury was the voice of The People. These days, I admit, I skip it. I also skip a lot of the news. Too much information, too little trust, too hard to parse, and those teeny tiny words squished into small boxes in the comics? Maybe leftover from the LSD of the 70s.
@Sam Corbin - Recent Doonesbury strips (new ones every Sunday) are just as topical today as they always have been. Trudeau speaks truth to power. In the best way.
I wonder if Sam knows Ross Trudeau.

@retired, with cat

Ross Trudeau's mother is Jane Pauley.
@Sam Corbin Here’s Sunday’s Doonesbury. It might ring a bell here because it’s about words :) https://www.washingtonpost.com/doonesbury/strip/archive/2025/5/18
@Convoid-04 ps Although I have to add I think the banned word site in the QR code was banned/s. I don’t know if that’s part of the joke or not!

@Barry Ancona
I guess maybe she does not.

@Dutchiris
Yes, she is.  Jane Pauley was a reporter and weekend anchor at WISH-TV in Indianapolis after her graduation from IU-Bloomington, Will Shortz’s Alma mater and mine; I worked in Indianapolis while she was at WISH-TV, and have followed her stellar journalism career.
@Dawn same here - felt it was so straight forward, even for a Monday! Got stuck a bit in the SE corner but overall was a great start to the week!

@Cat Lady Margaret

Brilliant, CLM!  O, Live Gar Den and prosper!

As a food snob I can't tell one chain eatery from another, especially in the US. Did you know Panera Bread (which I remember as a very sad place to work and eat at from the brilliant series 'What we do in the shadows') has the same number of letters as OLIVE GARDEN?

@Andrzej

This reminds me of something I tried to post yesterday, but which was apparently "eaten by the emus."

I commented that BIALYS are named after the city of Bialystok in Poland, and wondered whether bialys still exist in Poland (now that the segment of the population that created them is largely gone).
 
Can you enlighten us?
@Andrew Kennelly   I appreciate just being able to relax with a Monday puzzle.

@The X-Phile

To avoid posts being invisible, reply always to the original post rather than to any of the replies. That's what I'm doing here, replacing the @ with your handle.

We discussed bialy on the board several months ago. 

When I first encountered bialy in the NYT crossword, I was surprised. It's not known in Warsaw at present. I wouldn't know about the city of Białystok - even though it's one of our major cities I only ever was there once, and for a day only. I can't find any modern references to Bialystoker kuchen being popular anywhere in Poland. However, in 2020 it was included by the minister of agriculture on the list of traditional foods of the Podlasie region, but its described there as an historical rather than current thing. I'm not providing a link since it's all in Polish.

Some Jewish food in Poland survived the horrors of our 20th century history, like chałka, which you may know as challah or hallah. Most was lost...

Oikofuge,

Interesting. I knew the word FAE in the original sense* but did not know it as clued in the puzzle.

*from Wiki:
Latinate fae, from which fairy derives, is distinct from English fey (from Old English fǣġe), which means 'fated to die'. However, this unrelated Germanic word fey may have been influenced by Old French fae (fay or fairy) as the meaning had shifted slightly to 'fated' from the earlier 'doomed' or 'accursed'.

Faerie fire cast as on my character as a debuff by druids haunted my player-versus-player escapades in World of Warcraft 20 years ago: it prevented my Night Elf hunter from melding into the shadows, from where she would one-shot unsuspecting orcs, undead, trolls and Tauren.

Fun times.

The OED has nothing on the lore of fantasy games 🤣

@Oikofuge
In particular, "Fairies" or "Faeries" were blamed for "changelings"--children who did not develop normally.  It must have been a terrible time to have a child whose defects or differences were seen as the work of non-human or evil beings...  Cultures had different ways of dealing with these events--exposing the babe on a hillside or in a forest, for instance.

@Call Me Al

Many of the homes we lived in were older, smaller, or had fewer amenities--for instance, one bathroom shared by all--children dressing for school, dad preparing to drive to work...  so dad shaved in the kitchen, using  a mirror mounted on a cabinet door.  I thought it was normal. (No lotions or after-shave.)

Congrats on your pangram, Eric!

@Eric Hougland

I start every Spelling Bee by staring at the letters until the pangram takes a bow and it's first on my list of words.  I find pangrams more easily if my eyes are fresh and I don't get bogged down in the flurry of easier words that follow.  I never write anything on paper for the same reason: words are easier to see if the letters are just swimming around in your head.

So far, according to the Stats list, I have solved 660 puzzles, with 21,238 words, 809 pangrams and 656 Geniuses. The real geniuses rack up Queen Bees every day, and I have only 3 of those. I finally get too frustrated and bored to continue.

My real point is that finding a pangram is easier if you go for them first.  Genius will always follow.

@Dutchiris

Thanks for the suggestion. Some days, I immediately see a pangram and some days it takes a while.

I'm always afraid that I will see a word and forget it if I don't enter it immediately. (I've done that on days when I've decided to try to get to Genius without any four-letter words.)

I try for Queen Bee once or twice a week. But there's often some word like HAMATE (May 15) that I never would have come up with. So if I get Genius and find the pangram(s), I'm usually done with the Bee.

@Eric Hougland

I agree with so many others who have said that the Spelling Bee word list seems arbitrary, with words that are common but not accepted for the puzzle, e.g., dado (there are many in every house, in every room), and a lot of fairly common medical words that also get the boot.  And lobo is AOK, but not mañana (maybe it's the tilde).

The Queen Bee is really too hard for me, and the times I got it right were when I took a flyer on words that seemed like they could be words, and to my surprise were accepted.

Recently on Jeopardy Ken Jennings was chatting up a contestant about the Bee, and I think they both said they always got Queen Bee.  Impressive..

@The X-Phile

"Or easy gold at the hand of fae or elf." From Robert Frost's "Mowing".

@The X-Phile

Also, isn't it interesting how folklore varies from culture to culture? Fairies, ogres, trolls - none of that features in Polish folktales. In their stead we have Baba Jaga, sirens, basilisk, devils, magical animals, and enchanted knights. Take Warsaw: a siren features in one of the legends about the founding of Warsaw, a basilisk was said to have infested the Old Town once, and whoever finally manages to find the elusive Golden Duck in the dungeons below the Ostrogski castle will acquire limitless riches. Not a fairy in sight though.

@Andrzej

Once our explanation for the inexplicable involved all sorts of mysteries, and those mysteries were generally frightening and menacing (as "the unknown" usually is).

Our modern world is "disenchanted" (to use Max Weber's phrase).  We "know" that there is a rational, scientific explanation for everything.
It's easy to see the advantages of our modernism.  What we have lost is harder to see, but perhaps greater.

@Bill

I *think* it's actually a deliberate and considered effort by fantasy writers to get away from the cutesy Disney fairies, and back to the ambigious-to-malignant fairies of Celtic/ British mythology---Sithean, in Scottish Gaelic, who lend their name to many landscape features hereabouts.
Tolkien was trying to do the same thing when he coined "dwarves".

You'll find the Fae bear scant resemblance to Tinkerbell!

Oikofuge,

Get away from the Disney version to be sure, but J. M. Barrie's Tinkerbell would be just fine as a FAE.

You, in particular, @Oikofuge, might find this interesting: The OED has several listings for "fae," including a Scottish variant of "far"(is it?). But also, a variant of "Faa," as in "gypsy," as in Johnnie Faa: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6LaadVeQbZI (This wasn't the version I was looking for, by the Canadian group Puirt a Baroque, but . . .wow!) But I wonder if the inference was that there was something about gypsies* that was otherworldly, fay? (Doesn't Johnnie Faa make an appearance in those dreadful Philip Pullman novels?) *I use "gypsy," and not "Romani," purely in a literary sense.

@Bill (sorry to keep blathering on . . .)

"They coost the glamer o'er her . . ."

In truth, I had no problems or difficulty with FAE, and I realize why a writer might want to use a variant form--"after all, some of my best friends are Faeries," he said, Radically

Anyone interested in fairy-stories for the adult, New Yorker-reading set, should check out *Kingdoms of Elfin*  by Sylvia Townsend Warner.

@Bill

In Scots, "fae" is the more common variant of "frae", meaning "from".

I once had a cross-purposed conversation with a patient having a procedure under local anaesthesia.

"Are you comfy [comfortable]?" I asked.
"Aberdeen," he replied.
(He had understood me to be asking, "Far d'ye come fae?" Which is "Where do you come from?" in the Doric dialect of northeast Scotland.)

The Faws (Faes, Faas) got their name from a common surname among the Lowland Roma---indeed the Faas were a "royal" Roma family during the 19th century. I went to school with a McPhee, which is another common variant.

@Eric Hougland

Gobsmacked by the Olive Garden "joke" at your sister's funeral. The kind of thing it's impossible to forget, landing as it did at a time when your and your family's feelings were so vulnerable. I gasped so loud my husband asked what happened.

@Dutchiris

Thank you.

I sometimes wonder what was going through that woman's head when she decided to make that joke. It would have been different if she'd simply said something like "Andrea and I would have lunch at Olive Garden and she'd find it hard to resist the bread sticks." Nobody would have blinked an eye at that kind of memory. (And nobody would have laughed.)

I get that she might have been nervous speaking to a roomful of strangers, but it didn't seem that way at the time.

"Gobsmacked" is a great word, isn't it?

@K W

In the 1980s when I was a kid, oranges were a rarity in Poland, as few Soviet-aligned states produced them, so they almost never made it to our shelves. Imports from the "West" were not a thing.

In the 90s democracy and market economy changed everything. Oranges - and all the other goods previously so exotic - suddenly were everywhere.

But I still had no idea what an orange grove looked like.

I started travelling around Europe, sure, but given school schedules, I did that in the summer, when the oranges had already been picked.

I finally saw groves of orange trees laden with fruit only in my 40s! Over the past few years my wife and I have been beent trying to get away from Warsaw for a week or so in winter or spring. In the Kolymbethra gorge among the ruins of the ancient city of Akragas in Sicily in January, in Spanish Andalucia in February and on the plains of Greek Argolis in April we saw and smelled the awsomeness that is an orange grove. Wow! I'm so happy to have experienced that :)

@K W

I’m sorry to hear that the orange groves are gone. 

I don’t know about other people my age a few days shy of 65). But when they tore down something in Austin (where I lived for almost 40 years) and built something new, within a few years, I couldn’t remember what the place used to look like. 

It’s a bit different when more-or-less open country gets turned into suburbia, but eventually it seems like it’s always been that way. (Huge sigh over the automobile-centric land use policies in this country.)

Hang on to those memories.

@K W  We have a ten feet tall mock orange in our backyard, in full bloom right now, covered with beautiful, fragrant blossoms.  It's not the same as an orange grove, but think about shopping for one in a pot.  Ours is more than 50 years old (here when we bought the house), but in the right setting one will flourish and at least you will have that sweet smell again.
@K W 65 years on this earth as a native Floridian. Nothing smells better than the orange blossoms. Will always be my favorite fragrance. Jo Malone is the only one I wear.
